{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3368509,"name":"Matthew Milunic","username":"mathum","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/8baadc/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-21T22:03:10.084Z","cooked":"

Dean Kamen’s interesting speech promoting his company’s XRP bot got me generally thinking about how it would be nice if we could have a nice way to run WPILib based code on hardware we already have plenty of: old RaspberryPis. I know that the Romi system runs on a RaspberryPi 3b/4 plus another Romi 32U4 control board. Firstly, is the requirement for the system to be a RaspberryPi 3b/4 solely for the purposes of WiFi connectivity? If it is, old radios can be used as WiFi access points to the RaspberryPi pretty easily. Additionally, then cheaper RaspberryPi 1s that teams may already have but have no real use for as a coprocessor anymore could be put to use. (Our team specifically also received a donation of around 15 RaspberryPi 1s.) Secondly, is the Romi board really a requirement the system to work, or could you just hook the Pi straight up to PMW of say, an old brushed motor controller and have it work? If the Romi robot project is not the way to accomplish this, is there another way? I understand that the Websocket protocol is standardized to make things like this easier to accomplish, but I would like to know if there is already an implementation solely for RaspberryPi silimar to that for Romi and XRP. Sorry for any typos or formatting issues, I typed this up flying home form Houston. Thank you for any help!

bb-frc-workshops/xrp-wpilib","clicks":0},{"url":"https://github.com/wpilibsuite/wpilib-ws-robot-romi","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - wpilibsuite/wpilib-ws-robot-romi","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59542,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lead Bug Writer"},"post_url":"/t/can-you-run-wpilib-on-a-raspberrypi-through-simulation/463826/1","custom_user_title":"Lead Bug Writer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3368520,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-21T22:14:55.231Z","cooked":"

How both the Romi and XRP work with WPILib is that WPILib runs in simulation on the desktop and sends motor commands / receives sensor feedback over a WiFi connection to a process running on the robot side. What’s different between the two is the protocol and the nature of the robot side processing (due to different hardware).

Romi: robot is Raspberry Pi, protocol is websockets (which you linked to). The robot side process is a node application: GitHub - wpilibsuite/wpilib-ws-robot-romi
XRP: robot is Pi Pico (RP2040), protocol is custom UDP. The robot side “process” is a firmware image for the RP2040 (since there’s no OS): GitHub - wpilibsuite/xrp-wpilib-firmware

We use a Pi3b+ for the Romi because that’s what the WPILibPi image supports and it has built-in WiFi. I don’t think the robot-side processing needs all that much horsepower, but we’ve never tried running the node process on a Pi 1. It might be too heavyweight, in which case a port of the XRP firmware might be a better fit?

Yes, you’re going to need something to drive servo-style PWM controls; the Pi can’t do this directly (to my knowledge). Something like this should work? https://www.sparkfun.com/products/15316

Note if you’re driving any kind of mechanism or drivetrain with larger brushed motors, you must think about safety. The websocket and XRP protocols and implementations have minimal safety features, as they’re driving plastic things that weigh less than a couple pounds. Being UDP based, the XRP protocol is a little safer of a starting point, as at least you can time out if packets stop arriving, but the simulation GUI has no e-stop type features.

Over the offseason last year we had success controlling brushed motors using built in PWM pins on the RaspberryPi 1 and the TalonSRX. Here’s the code we used to do that. Our approach to safety last year for them was basically have them geared down so far and that they couldn’t go fast enough to be a danger and also have it kill the motors if it received no ping from the website we used to control it for too long. (We also had a stop button on the website and a remote kill command loaded on a computer the whole time.)

PS. Thanks for the insanely fast response too!
